title: Capitalization
description: Test your knowledge of proper capitalization rules in Canadian English

questions.question: What are the three basic uses of capital letters in English?
options: Beginning of sentences, people's names, and place names
Official documents, legal writing, and technical writing
questions.explanation: Capital letters have three basic uses: (1) to give emphasis, as in official titles and initial words; (2) to distinguish proper nouns and adjectives from common ones; and (3) to highlight words in headings and captions.

questions.question: Which of the following should be capitalized? (Select all that apply)
options: The first word of a sentence
The first word of a direct quotation that is itself a complete sentence
The first word after a colon if it introduces a complete sentence
Every word after a quotation mark
questions.explanation: Capitalize the first word of a sentence and the first word of a direct quotation that is itself a complete sentence. Do not capitalize the first word after a colon unless it introduces more than one sentence or a formal statement. Not every word after a quotation mark is capitalized.

questions.question: How should nicknames and epithets be capitalized?
options: Capitalize nicknames when they replace the person's name
Always use quotation marks instead of capitals
Only capitalize if the person is famous
questions.explanation: Capitalize a nickname or epithet replacing a person's name, or a nickname or by-name used with the name: Alexander the Great, Ivan the Terrible.

questions.question: Proper adjectives derived from proper nouns are always capitalized.
questions.explanation: False. Most words derived from proper nouns are capitalized (Canadian values, Shakespearean), but some have lost their association and are lower-cased (brussels sprouts, french fries, scotch whisky).

questions.question: Which is the correct capitalization for a government department?
options: the Department of Health (full name), the department (short form)
questions.explanation: Capitalize the full name of a government department or agency, but lower-case short forms: the Department of Health, but: the department issued new guidelines.

questions.question: Which institutional names are correctly capitalized? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Capitalize the full, official names of institutions and organizations. However, generic short forms like 'the university' or 'the church' are lower-cased unless they form part of an official title.

questions.question: How should political movements be capitalized?
options: Capitalize only when part of an official party name
Capitalize only communist and socialist movements
questions.explanation: Capitalize political parties but not movements or ideologies unless they form part of the official party name: the New Democratic Party, but: democratic socialism, communism.

questions.question: When should a job title be capitalized?
options: Only when it directly precedes the person's name
When it directly precedes the name or is used in direct address
questions.explanation: Capitalize a title of office or rank when it directly precedes a personal name or is used in direct address: Prime Minister Trudeau, but: Justin Trudeau, the prime minister.

questions.question: Former titles retain capitalization: 'Former President Obama spoke at the event.'
questions.explanation: False. Do not capitalize former titles: former president Barack Obama, not Former President Obama.

questions.question: Which sentence correctly capitalizes a personification?
options: We must stop time from running out.
We must stop Time from running out.
The crown is made of gold.
questions.explanation: Capitalize vivid personifications: 'the march of Time,' 'Fate's fool.' Also capitalize metonymic nouns like 'the Crown' (representing the monarchy).

questions.question: Which family appellations are correctly capitalized? (Select all that apply)
options: I saw Mother at the store.
I saw my mother at the store.
questions.explanation: Capitalize family appellations when unmodified (Mother, not my mother), when followed by a name (Grandmother Smith), or in direct address (Hello, Father).

questions.question: How should racial, linguistic, and national groups be capitalized?
options: Capitalize all terms for races and nationalities
Capitalize national groups but not racial terms
questions.explanation: Capitalize names of races, languages, and peoples: English, French, Inuk, Indigenous peoples, Asian. Also capitalize Black when referring to people of African descent.

questions.question: Which is correct for school subjects?
questions.explanation: Do not capitalize the names of school subjects except for languages and course titles: She studies history, French, and biology, but: She's taking History 101.

questions.question: Military ranks should always be capitalized, even when used generically.
questions.explanation: False. Capitalize military ranks only when they precede a name or are used in direct address: General Smith, but: the general arrived.

questions.question: How should ship and aircraft names be written?
questions.explanation: Capitalize and italicize the names of specific ships, aircraft, and spacecraft: HMCS Ville de Québec, Air Force One. Do not italicize abbreviations like HMCS.

questions.question: Which is the correct capitalization for awards?
questions.explanation: Capitalize the names of medals, awards, honours, and decorations: Nobel Prize in Physics, Order of Canada, Victoria Cross.

questions.question: Which time references should be capitalized? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Capitalize historical periods (the Middle Ages), named decades (the Roaring Twenties), and days/months (Monday, January). Do not capitalize centuries (the twentieth century) or seasons (spring, summer).

questions.question: How should cultural movements be capitalized?
questions.explanation: Capitalize names of cultural, intellectual, and philosophical movements: the Renaissance, the Enlightenment, Romanticism.

questions.question: Which religious terms are correctly capitalized? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Capitalize sacred books (the Bible, the Koran), terms for the deity (God), and nouns or pronouns referring to the deity. The adjective 'biblical' is lower-cased.

questions.question: How should the word 'god' be capitalized when referring to deities?
questions.explanation: Capitalize God when referring to the deity in monotheistic religions, but lower-case when referring to pagan deities: the ancient Greeks worshipped many gods.

questions.question: Which geographical term is correctly written?
options: the East coast of Nova Scotia
questions.explanation: Capitalize official place names (New Brunswick) but not compass points used descriptively (northern). However, capitalize compass points when they have political connotations: the West, the Far North.

questions.question: The names of buildings and monuments should always be capitalized when used in plural.
questions.explanation: False. Do not capitalize when used in plural or generically: the National Gallery, but: national galleries; St. Andrew's Church, but: an Anglican church.

questions.question: When should 'earth,' 'sun,' and 'moon' be capitalized?
options: Only when mentioned in relation to other planets
questions.explanation: Capitalize earth, sun, and moon only when mentioned in relation to other planets: 'The sun shines brightly' but 'Mercury is closer than the Earth to the Sun.'

questions.question: In biological classifications, which should be capitalized?
questions.explanation: Capitalize the genus but not the species: Sporotrichum schenkii. Capitalize phylum, order, class, and family names as well.

questions.question: Which chemical and medical terms are correctly written? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Do not capitalize chemical elements (sodium bicarbonate) or generic drug names (phenobarbital). Capitalize personal names in medical conditions (Huntington's chorea). Chemical symbols follow standard practice (H2O).

questions.question: How should book titles be capitalized?
options: Capitalize major words but not articles, conjunctions, or short prepositions
questions.explanation: Capitalize the first and last words and all major words in titles. Lower-case articles (a, an, the), coordinating conjunctions, and prepositions of three or fewer letters: The Canadian Style.

questions.question: Which reference to a book part is correct?
questions.explanation: Capitalize specific references to major divisions (Chapter 3, Appendix B, Table 4) but not minor subdivisions (page 45, line 12, note 6).

questions.question: Terms indicating time or numbered sequence should be capitalized when followed by numbers: 'Day 15,' 'Highway 401.'
questions.explanation: True. Capitalize common singular nouns followed by a date, number, or letter to denote time or sequence: Day 15, Highway 401, Room 234, Flight 204.

questions.question: In legal writing, how should acts and legislation be referenced?
options: Always capitalize short forms of acts
Capitalize full names; lower-case short forms used generically
questions.explanation: Capitalize the full official name (the Financial Administration Act) but lower-case short forms used in a general sense: 'Parliament discussed the new white papers before it adjourned.'

questions.question: In hyphenated compounds, how should proper nouns be treated?
options: The proper noun retains its capital
questions.explanation: A proper noun or adjective in a hyphenated compound retains the capital: Greco-Roman, neo-Nazi, trans-Canada, Pan-American.
